intro: Matelea hamata, commonly known as the spiked matelea, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its distinctive, spiky seed pods. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its flowers are usually yellow or greenish-yellow, and it produces small, round seeds enclosed in a hairy, elongated pod. Matelea hamata is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in supporting local wildlife.
